description.text: It is a small back flow chiller. Through the outer cavity you are able to pump a hot or cold fluid. Through the inner tubing you may pump a fluid which in turn gets heated or chilled by the other fluid. The two fluid are except for the transfer of heat isolated form each other. They will not mix.

If you want to print one, use the BackFlowChillerComplete.stl file. This file is not a version of the chiller with a cutaway to expose the inner structure of the thing.
I don't know how well the makerbot will cope with the overhang of the top covering. If to much sagging occurs you could alway add some more support pillars in the sagging area to keep it level.

For some reason, I thought it would be nice to place my phone on a hand while charging. This is a hand (remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680395) that holds a little Qi charger in its palm, on which you place your (Qi wireless charging enabled phone), like a modern Samsung, an iPhone 8 or X, or any other phone with a Qi add-on.
For stability, the base is a power bank, which is nice and heavy, so the whole assembly doesn't move around on your table or nightstand. It also allows for fully wireless charging without a socket!

Of course, you need matching components. The following links are from a Dutch store, but I'm sure you can find them elsewhere. Especially the Qi charger (diameter 69 mm, height 9 mm) is all over the internet for only a few euros/dollars. In case you wish to use different components, I've included the Blender file (for the hand) and Solidworks (for the battery compartment), so you can customise it to your gear.

What I used:

Qi Charger, 7 euro from allekabels.nl : https://www.allekabels.nl/draadloos-opladen/11543/1350614/qi-oplader-700-ma.html

12000 mAh Power Bank, 13 euro from allekabels.nl: https://www.allekabels.nl/oplaadbare-batterij/1052/1392969/oplaadbare-batterij-telefoon.html

Please note: I am not affiliated with this web store in any way,

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0 with Repetier 0.92

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print the hand standing up. The base (wrist) is flat for this purpose. Supports are not required. Please note: the hand is huge! The entire print stands almost 20 cm tall, which is the limit of my printer. It cost about 250 g of filament at this size and 20% infill.
When scaling, bear in mind that you'll also scale the circle that the Qi charger has to sit in. If you just want to scale the hand, do it in Blender.

The battery box and its base are best printed separately, with the battery box upside down.

I would recommend printing this in PLA, which is what I did. My bed temperature was 50 degrees and I have a kapton sheet on my bed.
The only other plastic I have experience with, ABS, would probably warp terribly on the battery box components

The parts are simply glued together. The back of the hand is flat, so you can glue it onto the battery compartment. But first insert the power bank and glue the base of the box (that has some openings for no other reason than to save filament, although it adds to the printing time) together.

As a finishing touch, I added some silicone feet under the battery compartment, to stop it from sliding around.

I took the hand and loaded it into Blender. Using boolean operations, I cut out a cylinder of 70 mm. I then used two scaled cubes and more boolean operations to cut a flat piece on the wrist (for printing) and the back of the hand (for glueing).

The battery box was a pretty straightforward design I did in SolidWorks at work. I sized it to the power bank I had bought and made a cutout so you can see the battery indicator.
I made the base of the box separate, so that the box can be easily printed in two pieces without support material.

title: I2C Game Controller for Arduino / Raspberry Pi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As part of my LED-Matrix Table project (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z7gvpGvGYsc) , I designed this game controller to control the table and to play games. It can be used as an input device for a wide variety of micro-controllers or raspberry pi computers.
Up to 8 controller can be used in parallel with the same control chip. The state of the eight buttons can be read by using the I2C protocol and therefore it only requires 4 wires for connection.

Additional Parts

The chip, included in the controller, is a PCF8574 on a small circuit board from Amazon (8€):
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B06W564ZSD
And the pushbuttons are from Ebay (1.2€):
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10-Stück-DIP-4-Mini-Drucktaster-Printschalter/272861590169

Additionally, you need a few wires for connecting the buttons to the PCF8574 chip and a 4-wire-cable with approx. 2 meter length to connect the controller to the raspberry pi.

Instructions

  • Print all parts :)
  • Cut out two perfboard pieces with a dimension of 40x40 mm each.
  • Solder 4 buttons on each perfboard, pay attention to the proper alignment (use the X button as reference, both perfboards require the same alignment)
  • Connect one pin of each button to the I2C port extender. Connect the other pin of each button to GND on the port extender circuit board.
  • Slide the two prefboards into their rails and use hotglue to fixate them (check if the align with the corresponding button holes as good as possible.
  • Connect the long cable to the port extender board. If you use the same board, you have to desolder the i2c connector on both sides.
  • Fixate the port extender board with some hotglue in the center of the controller as shown in the the pictures above.
  • Connect the other end to your arduino / raspberry pi and you are done.
  • Have fun! :)

Multi-color

Multi-color printing of the front side of the controller can be achieved by pausing the print before layer 2 and 4 (0.2 mm layer height). Print layer 2 and 3 in a different color to achieve the colored inset, seen in the pictures above.

description.text:
I made this direct extruder for my CL-260 Ultimaker clone. It works with the original motor too because the extruder case is a little bit bigger than the original one and can hold the wiight very well. I suggest you to use a smaller one just if you want to print faster.

This system is compatible with:

  • Zortrax original heatsink and hotend
  • Microswiss heatsink and hotend for Zortrax M200

I suggest to print all the parts in polycarbonate, nylon or petg. Probably abs will not hold the heat from the hotend. I used parts printed in sls with nylon pa66.

For the assembly you will need every type of m3 screws you can find. Many of them are customized. You can cut them to size for a perfect fit. This is not easy at all!
You will pray someone to end your life while you try to install this upgrade. I WARNED YOU MY FRIEND! xD
Use 40mm fans and you are good to go ;) I prefer the ones with leds inside because i do not see a shit :D

50% min

Notes:

I suggest to print all the parts in polycarbonate, nylon or petg with at least 50% of infill and 0.1 layer height if you can.

Simple holder for dioder from Ikea to use on 8mm steel tubes (like on many 3D printers).

This plug was designed for Hatchbox 1.75 PLA may work with others.

I was using other "Clips" but they kept flying off so I designed this plug. It is pretty tight - so it has a better chance to not fall off. Note that not all holes in the reel are the same size. I found two on my test reel that are too small for the plug. If you can't get it through the hole from the inside, insert it from the outside then try to insert it from the inside again.

Snip any melted/deformed filament from the end, insert the plug from the inside of the reel and thread the filament through the plug.

NOTE: Remove plug before printing or it may get hung on the filament.

Included are two versions. The short version sits flush with the reel in order to keep the box (if you keep filament in the original box) from bumping the plug.

title: Cellular automaton snowflake generator in OpenSCAD

description.text:
By default this cellular automaton uses Stephen Wolfram's rule that a filled cell stays filled and an unfilled one becomes filled if it has exactly one filled neighbor.

You can vary the rules and even include indeterministic rules. For instance, one can set chance the probability of generation when there is one neighbor to 0.5, so the generation parameters are 0,0.5,0,0,0,0,0. These more snowflake-like to me than the defaults (see the light blue image). Another interesting set of generation parameters is 0,0.5,0,0.1,0,0,1 (0.5 chance of generation with one neighbor; 0.1 chance with 3 neighbors, certainty with 6 neighbors).

https://youtu.be/sJjrz4mL5aA

Christmas 2017 update: Added join mode, where neighboring nodes are joined with a fat line instead of there being a hex at them.

A snowball pyramid for those tea lights with LEDs, which you find everywhere these days. Use 1+3 snowballs for a two-story pyramid 1+3+6 = 10 snowballs for a three-story pyramid.

Optional step: replace the coin cell batteries by a common 3V power supply. I used this one, which works with a powerbank or a mobile charger.

I printed in clear(-ish) PETG using 0.8 mm nozzle and 0.5 mm layers for a reasonably quick print.

Building the pyramid

The snowballs fit together in a ring of three or a ring of six.

The topmost snowball stands on a ring of three snowballs. There is a flat surface near the top of each snowball, which fits with a corresponding surface near the bottom (there are three of them at the bottom).

Each of the three snowballs in the middle layer stands on two snowballs of the bottommost layer.

Ring of six snowballs. Note the flat surfaces near the top and how they face towards each other in pairs. Two-story pyramid, consisting of 1+3 snowballs. Optional step: add power supply

LED-lights are commonly powered by 3.3V coin cells, which may last around 24 hours. To save the planet and a lot of hassle, the batteries can be replaced by a common power supply, which is used by all the lights of the pyramid.

Soldering wires to the battery holder. Red is +, black is -. Note that polarity matters for LEDs, won't work the other way around. There's a hole at the base for wires.

Filament holder Prusa I3 M605

author: Mario_Hoelli

description.text:
There is no shortage of excellent plans for IKEA Lack based printer enclosures but I wanted to make my own anyway since it's fun...

The key difference between this one and the other ones I found is that it is designed to be very easy to take apart. The hinges are on the bottom edge of the panels and connected to the bottom table, which means that the panels when fully opened are hanging down the sides of the bottom table and that the upper table can simply be lifted off when the printer needs service.

Since all four panels are identical the enclosure can be opened from all sides. The hinges are also designed so the panels can easily be lifted off after opening just a little bit, so placing the printer against a wall doesn't make it difficult to lift off the upper table.

I also didn't want to raise the upper table, which means that there is not much space above the printer. In practice this means that there must be a wide slot for the filament instead of just a single hole. I designed a slot with maximum width printable on my prusa I3 mk2, but there are lots of others to choose from, no need to use my version.

I thought long and hard about what to do with the display unit since it doesn't quite fit in the enclosure while also making room for the Y-cable on the back. In the end I decided to simply make a cutout for the display in the front panel, since I'm not aiming for a completely sealed unit anyway. I might try to design something to cover up most of the gaps around the display later, but I think it's nice to be able to use the display without opening the front panel.

The front panel cutout means that the printer must be pretty well lined up inside the enclosure, otherwise the front panel can't be closed. I solved this by combining something that keeps the printer in the correct position with a vibration absorber and making it ultra low profile so the printer still fits: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2723239

The panels need some kind of handle, and also some kind of lock. This combined handle and latch turned out to work really nice: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2703407

The mains cable also needs a solution. Again there are ready made similar things, but I made my own anyway (I'm new at cad and learning by doing is fun).

None of the parts need added support, but the hinge-pins and probably also the corners and hinges need a brim. Print the pins on the side for strength, they have a small flat section. The corner piece has support pieces included below the shelf on the inside, which is easy to cut away. If you are slicing with slic3r (and possibly other slicers also) you need to enable 'detect thin walls' in the print settings, otherwise the included support won't come out right.

The hinges and the linked handle are designed for 4mm sheets.

author: yahyah206

description.text: lighter case, recommended to climb to 1.05

A very simple character substitution-style encryption tube that is small enough to easily fit in your pocket or bag. There are 3 pre-randomized outer cylinders and inner rods labeled 1 - 3, and they can be used in any of 9 combinations of rod and cylinder. However, there is also a custom set that can be ordered however the user likes.

description.header: Optional Supports and Other Printing Must-Knows
description.text:
I have included files with and without supports, however, since I inserted the supports by hand, they may be insufficient or overly wasteful, you may consider using supports generated by a more refined program.

This model is also very small, and may therefore be too small to print without losing necessary detail. Increasing the scale may preserve said details, but remember that all tolerances will be magnified proportionally, so the parts will fit more loosely.

Know your code:

Each rod and cylinder have a number labeling them; the rod is labeled on the internal wall while the cylinder is labeled on the inside base. As well, there are notches on the bottom of the rod that allow the rod to rotate and lock in 6 positions, which are denoted by the numbers 1 - 6 on the top of the rod and an arrow on the edge of the cylinder.

By combining these 3 numbers, you have an encryption code, which you can note at the beginning of an encrypted note.

If you use the custom set, be sure to include the full 36 character set for each individual rod and cylinder. Having too few on one, or too many on another may mean it will be possible to substitute multiple characters for the same input (e.g. A -> 2, and, A -> F), so encryption would be lossy.

Get cipherin':

This cypher can be used only 2 ways. The first is to substitute the left character in a pair for the right, and the second is to substitute the right for the left.

--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--<==>--
This is an example of encryption using rod 1, cylinder 2, and position 3, read left to right

  1. hello world (encrypt test)
  2. 123, 7C66D GDL6Y;
  3. (decrypt test) hello world

description.text: my first design of replacement part throttle of grande retro scooter. handlebar diameter 25mm

This was modified from RoyToreHofstad's creation.
I moved the top screw holes toward the center, because most wall studs in my area are only 1.5 inches wide, and finding the exact edges of a stud is not easy.
I also extended the tips of the arms slightly vertical, so as to deter the guitar from falling if twisted on the mount.

I printed this on a Monoprice Mini Delta using Hatchbox Wood PLA, 0.1mm layers at 200°C.
The model was printed with the wall-face against the printer bed (arms pointing up, so as to reduce the need for supports).
I did use supports, however I'm not sure if they were really needed at all. I chose 50% infill, which felt very difficult to bend or break.
Print time was around 8 hours.
There were quite a few extra strings to remove after the print (I still need to tweek the settings for wood).

title: Random Snowflake Generator v11 ornament and earrings

description.text:
This is a random snowflake generator using the free BlocksCad on-line educational system.
12.24.2017 update: now generates either ornaments or earrings:

  • files with the word "earring" are sized for earrings
  • files without the word "earring" are sized for ornaments
  • BlocksCAD files are provided for both
  • the BlocksCAD file random_snowflake_earring_2.xml has a small improvement that better positions the attachment loop

The image shows two examples of snowflakes generated by the program provided.

Each click of the "RENDER" button creates a new snowflake.

To create a new snowflake, simply click the “render” button

  • If you like a snowflake click “Generate .stl” and the program will save the .stl to your downloads folder. If you click render again, you can’t go back; so save it to a file as soon as you see it if you think you might want to keep it.

.stl files are provided for two sample ornament sized snowflakes and 20 sample earring sized snowflakes that were generated by the .xml file in BlocksCAD https://www.blockscad3d.com/

added two files repaired using Netfabb (free) if you have trouble printing the files that came from BlocksCAD

The BlocksCAD project page is here: https://www.blockscad3d.com/community/projects/68417

Enjoy!

BlocksCADSnowflake

If you wish to modify the program, here are some of the key parameters:

  • max_radius - reduce this to create smaller snowflakes or increase for larger snowflakes (the actual radius of the snowflake can vary from 1 x max_radius to max_dX_factor x max_radius)
  • width - reduce or increase this to make the branches thicker or thinner (the actual branch thickness can vary from 1 x width to max_width_factor x width)
    thickness is the snowflake thickness and is constant

  • thickness - snowflake thickness in mm

    this program uses:

  • loops - "count with ..."
  • translate
  • rotate
  • if ... do, else if ... do
  • cube
  • cylinder
  • union
  • difference
  • random fraction
  • modules with inputs (like a subprogram so you don't need to repeat code)
    --- make_branch
    --- ran_1_to_n - return a random decimal number between 1 and n (as opposed to the built-in function "random integer from # to #)

title: Simple Modular & Customisable Picture Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple self-standing picture frame., knocked up in a few moments using Fusion 360.

You'll need to two of the corners with the feet for the bottom and then two of the bare corners for the top. The sides can then be scaled along their length to match the size of the picture you wish to frame. All pieces should print without support, but I put a brim around to prevent warping depending on the filament used.

I'd suggest putting a piece of board in with the photo, and sand each of the ends until smooth and then super-glue them together around the frame.

The quite dark gold filament I used for the frame for a picture of my kids (shown here) almost came out like bamboo.

description.text:
Merry Christmas from Philadelphia!
Here is a lovely cookie cutter in the shape of our dear Liberty Bell. It's great for sugar cookies, or gingerbread as pictured. There are interior details to show some of the headstock and the infamous crack.
Nothing 3D printed is really food safe because of the texture, but as long as you don't have dangly bits of plastic getting into the dough, and consider this a single-use cookie cutter, than you will be fine. It's <$.01 of plastic, so go ahead a print another next year.

Now available for purchase on cults3d
Designed in Fusion 360. Sweeps around tight concave corners are hard. Cookie cutters are surprisingly difficult to CAD.

I wanted an easy way to insert and remove batteries for charging. I modified One_Ying's battery holder design to use magnets as the contacts. I had some magnets from a damaged brushless motor, I made the holes for the magnets are about 2.5 x 7 mm. Magnets cannot take a lot of heat, so I wrapped a wire around the magnet and hot glued it down, it works fine, soldering would have been much hotter than the hot glue, and I'm not sure if it would stick.

I also found out that most of the RC model battery chargers (instructions: https://hobbyking.com/media/file/705098054X7478X35.pdf) have a setting for Lithium Ion batteries like the 18650 (it displays as "LiIo") so you can charge as fast as you dare, Although I read that the normal charge rate for the 18650 batteries I have is 1.25 amps. You do not need the balance leads if you are charging a single cell.
I created this for my mini CNC machine and it works very well. I am posting it here at the request of @fjn777. I can also share it on TinkerCAD if you want to modify it.

Vertical Offset mount for a 608 Bearing

This thing was specifically designed for and installed on my acrylic DIY CNC machine. That machine is still going through all sorts of changes (lately getting a laser head) and you can see it on my Projects on HackADay. It was designed in TinkerCAD and originally printed on a SolidDoodle 3. So far it works great.

This is a round tool caddy designed to store commonly used tools (mostly hex keys) handily on an optics table.

• Print 'toolcaddyround.stl'

  • Mount to 1/2" post (e.g. thorlabs.com/NewGroupPage9.cfm?ObjectGroup_ID=1266) with a 1/4"-20 bolt through the center, counterbored hole.

  • Mount post to table (probably with a post holder e.g. thorlabs.com/NewGroupPage9.cfm?ObjectGroup_ID=1268). Make sure to leave clearance for the drivers etc. that will be hanging through the caddy.
    • (If using this on an optics table with lasers bouncing around be mindful of shiny tools and their placement.) This caddy is designed (but not limited) to hold: 2 x 3/16" ball drivers 2 x hemostats (Thorlabs LMR1AP alignment tool [http://www.thorlabs.com/thorProduct.cfm?partNumber=LMR1AP] fits nicely in the hemostat slots) Hex keys:
    1 x 3/16"
    1 x 5/32"
    1 x 9/64"
    1 x 1/8"
    1 x 7/64"
    1 x 3/32"
    1 x 5/64"
    1 x 1/16" And a couple larger holes that will fit screwdrivers and what-have-you.

title: smaller and enhanced shower head with handle

description.text:
This is a remix of "Post-modernistic-pre-futural-or-so complete shower head with handle" by docpayce. Thanks, I liked this one!
But it seems that it is wasting a lot of water. So I made it a bit smaller.
I also added a bit inside so it's more stable.

(In the following I copied some of his text.)

The shower head is pretty basic and connects to a european standard showering hose (Whitworth G1/2 thread).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

100%

Notes:

  • Prepare for a long print.

  • Surprisingly, this seems to print best when the shower head top is on the print bed surface (so that the screw/threading is pointing upwards at an angle). The handle and the screw will print fine without supports, as the angles are all around 15° and the exterior bridging is very minor. All major bridging is inside the shower head and will not show on the final product.

  • I recommed to use quite a significant brim (5 mm or more) to have good bed adhesion.

  • Print with a little bit of overfill to be sure that the housing is waterproof. But not so much as to close down the small holes (they are 1.4 mm in diameter - so you need A LOT of overfill to actually close them).

holes

The holes are not all the way through. So you have to drill them.
The best thing is: you can drill them in whatever diameter you like!
I recommend 1.0 to 1.5 mm.
The bigger they are the more water comes out (obviously). That means more wasting but softer water jets.

author: E-Mat

title: Better base for Buffalo WZR-600DHP router

description.text: The so-called base that came with my new Buffalo WZR-600DHP router was a complete joke. It wouldn't actually attach in any way and the router was tilted and more likely to fall over if you tried to put it on the base than if you just left it off the base. So I scanned in the bottom of the router, picked off dimensions with gimp, and whipped out a base in openscad that actually supports the router and makes it quite difficult to knock over.
Just print, and push on bottom of router. It stays on nicely with just a friction fit.

description.text:
UPDATE - All parts print correctly, with correct sizing! Except the batwing holder, which is too big for my printer, and is mostly experimental.

I've now printed 7 of these, and built 5 keyboards into them. I've printed with PETG and woodfill PLA with no issue. I'm confident these cases will print with no issue :)

I've uploaded photos of the completed pile of different things on several boards.

Keyboard case for the Iris. I used data from Keebio's lasercut files to build this:
https://github.com/keebio/iris-case

The keyboard PCB this case is for can be purchased here:
https://keeb.io/products/iris-keyboard-split-ergonomic-keyboard?variant=1302742761502

Full disclosure - Mine printed a little squished, and the holes filled in, so I had to scalpel off about 1.8mm from the bottom of each switch-hole, but if you printed it better, this might not be an issue.

This is the first thing I ever designed, using a combination of online tools and TinkerCAD. Tent angle components yanked from the listed remixed object. that was super helpful for determining an angle I liked!

I printed the bottom and middle merged, and that was fine - I removed the plastic bumper on the pins. If you would like you can print a series of pieces like the lasercut cases, or use one or two to make it thicker depending on how you soldered your pro micro.

Direct Drive Extruder, for use with MK7 Drive gear. For use with 1.75mm Filament and the MakerGear Hot End.
My First Post.

You will need the following Drive Gear:
http://store.makerbot.com/mk7-drive-gear.html another source
http://twelvepro.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=51 and the following HotEnd:
http://www.makergear.com/products/operators-pack Pick the V3 GrooveMount for 1.75mm fiament with the .35mm Nozzle. Thanks to Mark Fuller for the original design this is based on. I have included the Inventor Fusion 2013 source file. NOTE: Make sure you print this in ABS, as the stepper motor will get hot, and of course, the hotend will get hot too. I recommend using Slic3r 0.8.4 or higher to print this with the following key settings:
Perimeters: 3
Solid Layers: 3
Fill Density: .45
Layer height .26
Use support material with overhang of 95. Print with Motor attachment plate facing the build platform.

comments.author: thantik

comments.text: I have tried a bunch of the tilt-idler designs, and really do no like them. They are necessary if you are using 3mm filament for loading, but the 1.75mm just does not need it. I have only had it jam one time so far, and it was my fault, I have the retract set way too high, and I was retracting hot filament into the gear, and it flattened out and started slipping.
What kind of motor (strength) would you need for this? I really like the idea of a direct-drive extruder, seems more effecient, right?

description.text: This is a Bunny cover for IPhone 5/5s/5c!! It will protect your phone of any holocaust! Lucky bunny ears included!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.2 mm

60

Very important for using it after printing!

Just enjoy!!

How to model a phone cover?

First you need the measures of the phone you are gonna make the cover! It doesnt matter if you dont have the phone, you can get a lot of drawings on Internet.
After that, you need a parametric software, like Autocad, SolidWorks or Catia, this time I have used SolidWorks only.
Finally you´ll need to print some prototypes in order to verify the measurements!

This is a remix of S+E's 1.2x Radial Fan mount for the all powerful 50x50x20 radial fans from Sunon like the GB1205PKV1-8AY (a LOT more powerful than stock ones, bigger, dual air intake, more RPM)

It has a wide but small air outlet hole that points directly at the nozzle, but a E3D silicone nozzle is required to avoid heating issues with the heaterblock.

Print with PETG or ABS,
PLA will melt.

A friend edited this for me in Solidworks (i have no skills), so the layout is not optimal and could be better. Wirecutters to the rescue if you need to widen the holes somehow.

This Wave procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats:
RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed
BMP sequence 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 17MB uncompressed
PNG codec AVI 256x256x256
PLY isosurface mesh 4.3M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 500K polygons
Version with supporting column -PNG codec AVI 256x256x256
Versions with supporting column - STL (reduced) 400k polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

description.text:
This is my first ever design of something that can be used. So its not perfect.
I would call it a prototype.

I would recommend using more then two AA batteries, as it doesnt seem to last very long.
Probably last several houres though.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The lithophane was printed with .4 nozzle, white PLA at .2 layer hight, mm/s and 100% infill.
The top and base was printed in PrimaSelect Wood filament, using a .6 nozzle, .3 layer hight and 50 mm/s. 50% infill. Base had 4 top and bottom layers, top had 4 bottom and 5 top layers.

Im not sure if you need to use support on the base, but i did just to be sure.
The base is printed with the upside down, the lid is printed the right way to get the same finish on top as the sides. You might be able to get a good result the other way also,

The lithophane is 97mm outer diameter, 95mm inner diameter and made with 3dpRocks.

Parts

I used a battery box with 2 AA batteries, but i would recommend to use 4 to get longer life.
The led chip is a 1w that runs at around 3 volts.
Just make sure the output voltage matches the led chip that you use.

The led chip got very hot after a minute of use so it needed cooling.
Used some copper and cut to 30x30mm to fit in the groove in the base.
Its 5mm thick. I then used some thermal glue to glue it in place (found it on ebay).
Used hotglue to glue the copper to the base and mount the whole lamp together.
Drilled some holes for a zip tie to secure the wires.

Two-piece spool support. We don't need no stinking bearings.

Holds a variety of 1kg spool sizes up to 210mm diameter or up to 95mm thick (not quite at the same time, but that would be bigger than 1kg).

The stop has a taper fit into the base, and should be inserted snugly, but not super tightly.

Ideally use with an adapter for the spool that provides a 13mm hole. If I have to design any, I'll add them as I need them.

The spool adapters shown in the photo come from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2334107 Run the customizer and specify a 13mm hole, and at least 10mm vane height to avoid problems at the base/stop connection.

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

45% triangular

Even though I left 1/4 mm clearance all around the rod on the stop that inserts into the base, this was a very tight fit initially. After pushing it in and out a few times, however, it loosened up just right and now fits exactly as intended.

Remember that the base of the rod is a taper fit, so don't jam that in too hard.

description.text: So my FTC team is using the Rev system for the first time and we wanted to attach some extrusions perpendicular to each other. title: Max Thrust Riot / ArtTech Devil / Horizon Hobby Aire-Batix 4S Battery Bay Extension
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This thing adds a hump to the original battery bay lid of the Max Thrust Riot, also known in some countries as the ArtTech Devil. This will allow the fitting of a 4S LiPo in the bay, with the safety of still having a bay lid. I have tested with a Turnigy NanoTech 2200mAh 4S, and it works a treat (see last photo). However, it would be worth adding some material to the front of the bay to stop the battery sliding forwards.

The new part is designed to clip on to the existing bay after you have cut away some material. The clips are more for alignment and ease of fitting; I have added material to the 4 edges to allow some CA glue to be used for a permanent fixture.

The part weighs 2 grams. The material removed from the original bay lid also weighed 2 grams.

EDIT: This is also the same air-frame as the new Horizon Hobby Aire-Batix 1.4m

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed this on my Prusa i3 Mk1 in PLA. My settings were:

Brim: 0
Material: 1.74 mm
Nozzle: 0.4
Layer height: 0.20
infill: 100%
Infill: Rectilinear
Minimum infill gap: 0.5mm
Bed temp: 50 C (60 C first layer)
Nozzle temp: 205 C (215 C first layer)
Speed: 40mm/s (60% first layer)

Removing the support wasn't fun. I'm new to 3D printing, so you guys may have better luck. If I had dual material with the option of using dissolvable supports, it would have been worth the money with this thing.

My support settings were:
Support only from the build plate
Pillar resolution: 4.00mm
Max overhang angle: 50 degrees
Support infill percentage: 30%
Dense layers: 0
Horizontal offest from part: 1.5mm

The images show the process for fitting the bay extension:

  1. Mark out the cut lines on the battery bay lid. Leave some material on the outer holes.

  2. Cut lid along the lines, I used a Dremel with a circular saw tool. Then grind down the gap between the outer holes and ensure there are no sharp edges.

  3. Smooth off any sharp edges left inside the bay lid.

  4. Fit the bay lid extension. Its up to you whether or not you choose to fix it with CA glue, but I would recommend using it; I feel the extension piece would come off during flight without CA.
Marked cut lines Tray cut out Sand down all sharp edges Finished cover
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360

title: Herrnhuter Stern
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Herrnhuter Stern is a typical Christmas decoration found all over Germany. The originals were made out of paper and held together by small pins. This one is a bit different but has the same overall style.

The models are designed to be printed in Vase/Surface mode with continuous extrusion. This makes it printable on almost any machine. I printed them using red Colorfab XT because its a good color and a bit more heat resistant. Heat resistant is good because I used hot glue to hold all the parts together and have a small lightbulb mounted in the middle.

You'll need to print 17 of the larger 4 sided points and 8 of the smaller 3 sided points for a complete Herrnhuter Star. I had no problems printing these and overall print time was about 17 hours.

This Fractal Cellular procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. I have also included PNG codec AVI versions, one of which "fades" at the edges (for making surfaces that don't end abruptly).
These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats: RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed BMP sequence 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 17MB uncompressed PNG codec AVI 256x256x256 PNG codec AVI 256x256x256 (faded 16vx at edges) PLY isosurface mesh 1.6M polygons STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 810K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

title: Pitan (as in printed Titan :-) Geared Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
31 Jan '18 - Fusion files included. They are a mess sorry! Corrected the spring size to 6mm OD, 12-15mm length and 0.8-1mm wire thickness

11 Jan '18 - Updated to v1.1 with smaller 695zz bearings, smaller bolts and lighter, more compact body. Using two mirrored Pitans, direct to E3D v6, we can have the nozzles as close as 22.8mm. Mirrored files are included

The E3D Titan is arguably the lightest end smaller standalone Geared Extruder you can buy.
Pitan is a cheap and easy to print "copy" of the Titan with no discernable performance differences between them
It has the same 3:1 gear reduction, easy to see/clean drive gear, supported path for 1.75mm and 3mm filaments and it can be used with any Titan mount, bowden or direct drive. Filament feed path is on the idler arm and just as easy to load like the original Titan and It has virtually the same number of parts.

You need:
1x Nema17 12.7N-cm stepper motor
1x M5x30mm Bolt
1x M5 Nylon Nut Or one 2mm high for a mirrored setup
1x M5 Washer OR print one
1x 11mm Mk8 Drive Gear
3x M3x30mm Hex Bolts
1x M3x15mm Hex Bolt
1x M3 Nut
1x M3x10mm Bolt OR 1x 3x10mm Screw for the Idler
1x M4x15mm Hex Bolt OR E3d Thumbscrew
1x M4 Nut
1x 6x15x1mm Spring - Ebay - 6mm OD/ 12-15mm length/ 0.8-1mm wire thickness
2x 695zz Bearings
1x 623zz Bearing

1x Bowden plastic coupling from https://goo.gl/aJjGJi in UK or in US https://goo.gl/Mda5wX
Or
1x Bowden Groove Mount from https://goo.gl/mu18Lo

-- See the remixes for 625zz Bearings and Bowden Metal Fitting --

A typical Pitan has the following printed parts:

  • Body
  • Cover
  • Idler Lever
  • Gear 1 (small)
  • Gear 2 (big)
  • 1mm Washer
  • Filament Guide (1.75 or 3mm)
  • Base ( ie "2-3mm Base" for the standard Titan holder, "45deg" for a Delta printer etc)
    Same goes for a Mirrored extruder, except you will obviously need the parts with "Mirror" in the title.

I hope the pictures show how the assembly will go

Few things to have in mind:

  • I haven't tested yet with 3mm filament.
  • I use cheap MK8 drive gears and they work well enough. I imagine something like these https://goo.gl/bJFeka sold by E3D work with less pressure on the idler bearing due to sharper teeth. Spare 625zz bearings are a lot cheaper though
  • Supports are needed only for the Idler Lever
  • I've printed everything in PLA, gears and filament guide at 80% infill, 100u layer hight and the rest at 200u, 50% infill
  • To check your sizing, test print 5mm of the "Body" first. It should be 42x42mm if you don't measure the bearing hole. There are 0.1mm tolerances on each side where a part touches the other. That means 12.2mm hole for a 12mm E3D V6 and the V6 fits well with a bit of pressure. Step files are included if you need to change sizes to suit your printer.
  • The small gear is tight and it needs to be forced on the axle down to about 1mm from the bottom.
  • Filament Guide only goes in one way, it has a notch on the tip that has to face up
  • You need to file a bit of the M5 bolt for the drive gear grub screw.
  • Fit the M5 washer between the large gear and the first bearing.
  • The Idler Lever bolt can also be fitted from the other side.
  • Make sure the two gears are aligned
  • I've used a bit of grease on the gears and under the M5 nut.
  • Tighten the M5 nut and drive gear screw last. Do the M5 nut tight then the grub screw and then loosen the M5 nut until you can move the gears easily by hand.
  • The M5 nut may get tight by itself over time. Make a mark on the bolt to see if it moves
  • Chamfer a bit the inside of the PTFE tube and push it all the way in the filament guide.
  • On my Kossel I'm using the two 2020 45deg mounts on X and Y towers. In the files you will also find a universal base and one straight mount
  • Parts with "Logo" in the title have the Making'Bug logo on them

If you are building your very first printer you can have this printed for you, just leave a message on my page https://www.facebook.com/MakinBug/

Kudos go to E3D for the Titan https://goo.gl/fcBWLu and to AxMod3DPrint for his Drakon Extruder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172854

https://youtu.be/MrS9Yidgano

Enjoy :-)

comments.author: amolteni

comments.text: Hi MakinBug!! Wonderful job!! I really like Tiitan and your adaptation is great! I just printed one but I'm getting a little problem... I'm trying to use it direct drive so I mount the E3D v6 direct in Pitan. if I mount it without the E3D v6, everything is fine, but when put the E3D v6 in place the corner when it stay simply doen't fit all right. Looks like the space is a little small for it's circunference. Do you experienced  something like this? If yes can you tell how better way to fix it? Thank you!! Continue with your great work!
comments.author: VSAlex

comments.text:
The hot end needs to be tight otherwise it will move during printing.
There is just 0.1mm tolerance on each side (12.2mm hole for a 12mm E3D V6) and the V6 fits well with a bit of pressure. https://imgur.com/a/IJm6P
You need to make sure your printed parts have the correct dimensions. https://imgur.com/a/W0kb0
First check if you over extrude, if not, increase the size of the part in your slicer, on x and y axes.
Failing that, take the step file and make the hole bigger.
Or, seeing you have already printed it, get a knife and/or a soldering iron and make some room for the V6. At the end make sure the hot end is straight and it doesn't move.
Let us know if you have any other problems
comments.author: VSAlex

comments.text: After some cutting and sanding I have it ok. Thank you! After in place I'll publish some photos.

comments.text: Thank you for the answer. I just measure my print and the dimensions are ok. I saw there's a very light warping in the corner but it is above the screw hole and looks like doesn't matter. Soon I can I'll try to sand or cut slightly to get it done. If I have any other problems I'll let you know.

comments.text: We'll wait and see if others have the same problem and increase the tolerances if requested.

comments.author: Slidr

comments.text:
I've used the edge of a flat metal file. No need to go too deep, 0.5mm or so, just to stop the gear from rotating under load
You can also do it with a hacksaw. Mark where the drive gear screw will go and do 4-5 cuts one next to the other.

remixed_from.author: CNCKitchen
remixed_from.title: Prusa MK2 Camera Bed Mount - Higher Arm

title: Prusa MK3 Camera Bed Mount Arm

description.text:
UPDATE 2-10-18:
Made a correction to the RIGHT side mount, it needed a little more clearance as the right side of the bed frame is not symmetrical to the left.

UPDATE:
I've added a separate RIGHT and LEFT side STL file (the right side option is admittedly much more convenient as it doesn't get in the way of the SD card slot like the left side does). FYI - I probably won't be working any more on this one, as it was really a quick and dirty solution for me. I have moved onto a new accessory rail design that I'll share soon. Stay tuned.

=====================

This is a remix of the previous MK2 version by robsgarcia, which is a remix of the "Prusa Camera Bed Mount - Higher Arm" by CNCKitchen, which is a remix of the original version by PrintCentral. I've modified this mount arm specifically for the brand-new PRUSA MK3 bed (released Nov 2017).

There are many older versions of this style of mount arm on Thingiverse, some even say "MK3" in the title. However none that I've seen actually fit the MK3 chassis. Several adjustments were necessary. First, the width of the bed chassis arm of the MK2 is only ~10mm, whereas the width of the arm of the new MK3 chassis is 12.3mm. So I widened the inner channel in this version to 12.33mm, which provides for a super snug fit on my MK3 bed rail. The prints made on my MK3 fit so tightly that it doesn't seem to need the screw that the original design called for. So I killed the screw slot and added two recessed zip tie slots across the bottom, which help guide the installation of a zip tie on each side of the silver spacer/post. After really ratcheting these down, the part seems solid enough. YMMV on the snugness depending on print tolerances.

I also significantly shortened section that connects to the bed so that it doesn't interfere with the Y-axis rod and the zip tie that's on it. Then I lengthened the middle section of the arm so that the extruder won't crash into the camera when the bed moves all the way to the back and the extruder is low.

The version of the Pi camera enclosure that I used is this one by hackoholic that allows the ribbon cable to exit the bottom instead of the top: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2352964

Thanks to all the original designers and remixers.

Prusa

Prusa Mk2

No

20%

print_settings.Notes:: supports only needed on the base part where the vacume hoses connect. Infill of 20% in enough but suggest increasing the layers - 5 should be max.

description.text:
I have remixed this cyclone THINGIVERSE 1447214, to use on my CNC machine. I needed connections for standard 2.25 inch vacume hoses a small caputure container with a wide mouth.

I made the cyclone from PLA with 6 layers and 30% infil. I think it is overbuilt and 5 layers with 20% should be enough. The remaining parts where 20% and 5 layers. The PLA makes nice treads but they need woking together for a smooth fit. The mason jar threads fit perfect with the peanut butter jars on first try.

The mason jar was a remix from CANNING JAR LIDS - THINGIVERSE 19105. I chose canning jars because they are readily avalable in grocery stores in durable clear plastic. Mine come from peanut butter jars. I have made an adaptor for small and large jars, so you can choose the size jar for your needs.

This cyclone does not attach at the base (witch is an advantage) and so needs to hanger. The hanger is printed from PETG, 5 layers 20% infil.

The vacume conntor part took 70 hours to print and is the only part needing supports. The cyclone part 30 hours, the hanger 20 hours and the adaptor 6 hours. It is a long print, be for me it was worth it.

description.text:
A tile set of Canals - Embankments and water tiles that snap-fit to keep larger arrangements together more easily. This set builds on the smooth stone tiles of devonjones for the embankments. Mostly compatible with OpenForge.

For this tile set I wanted to transition from embankment to water partway through a tile square, with part of the tile filled with embankment, and part with water. The embankment tile corners and edges are designed with this in mind.

The embankment tiles have multiple snap fit points, so each tile is easy to fit into any arrangement of water. For bodies of water wider that 5 squares, or for joining multiple canals together, there are water tiles with snap fit connectors at a single end, so the end without a snap-fit connector can abut another water tile, or any other type of tile.

description.text: After I made the Dark Knight magnet, I thought, I cant let him hang alone! I need to make his favorite tight wearing, Circus swinging sidekick! It is a Robin magnetic emblem for the refrigerator. Inspired by countless images and merchandise. Print one! The kids will love it, if not; the vigilantly circus freak inside you will love it! It uses 1/4 x 1/4 Inch Neodymium Rare Earth Cylinder Magnets N48 Magnets that I bought off of ebay from seller mfcom. There is plenty of clearance between the fridge and the body, so it is easy to remove, even with strong magnets. It is less than 3.5 inches wide (showing up the baby bat), but it does not take up much space.

Print it. Glue it. Holy Refrigerator Magnets Batman! Got the magnets here http://www.ebay.com/itm/1-4-x-1-4-Inch-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Cylinder-Magnets-N48-20x-Magnets-/151252338611?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item23375787b3. I used Loctite Super Glue to affix the magnets in. Use whatever fill you like. I used 50% rectilinear fill. There is a rectangular backer piece that could be a red background if someone would like to add it to their print. I thought it would make it too big, but included the file in case someone wants to use it. It just goes on the back over the magnet mount. I did not print it, so print at your own risk. it should fit, but I cant be positive. I just painted and glued the separate pieces together. If you have the correct colors of filament, all the better! I only had black and white.

title: Customizable 1 to 4 Gang Wall Switch Plate

description.text:
I really needed to print a couple of replacement 3-gang switch plates, but couldn't find any models on thingiverse that met my needs. So, I decided it would be a good way to learn openSCAD. The result is this thing: A very customizable wall switch plate. Currently, it supports only "decora", "toggle" and "blank" types, and only up to 4 gang wide.

However, boring switch plates are just that: boring. However, using the customizer, you can add labels to the switches, change the size of the plate (by default, it's slightly oversized) and tweak various parameters.

While some dimensions are able to be customized, others are hard-coded to meet industry standards. For example, switches in a multi-gang box are always 46.0375mm apart (center to center, gang to gang.) The sizes of the switch types and the screw hole placements are also industry standard. Sadly, "the industry" (that I'm able to reference) is all in imperial measurements, so everything is converted to metric.

If adding labels, try to keep them short. As you'll obviously see in the customizer preview, overly long labels will look bad, end up off the plate, etc.

author: Thetangeru

description.text:
This is a structure made of M8 threaded rods and 3D printed parts that can replace Geeetech i3 structure.
The extruder assembly is still a work in progress...I included the file if you fancy modifying it...
The rest is pretty much ok but there is still nothing designed to hold the electronics and the display.
The original Geeetech tensioning pulley for X and Y axis fits the respective plates.

The bearings, axis, Z rods (M8x1mm) and nuts, are the same measures of original Geeetech i3 (x=390mm,y=410mm,z=320mm).
The printing area is increased to about X=300mm, Y290mm, Z215mm.
Limit switches fixing areas are designed with "home" and "end" positions, except at the top of Z axis (that is not present anyway in Geeetech printer).

The rods are 12, M8, at max 500mm long, so it should all be done with 6x1000mm M8 rods.
There are holes on the Y axis plates for 2 extra threaded bars if needed to hold it tighter.
The X carriage axis are placed horizontally instead of vertically, interaxis 70mm.

In the files there is "Piastra fissaggio hotbed" that have the pattern for the holes to fit the bearing holders for the Y carriage.

Just a note if you are going to print this:
Some parts have pre-cuts and the slicer will build supports for them, but you have to handle the part together and not separate them when moving the part around in the slicer plate.
Just take a look at the parts when placing them in the slicer, there is always a side that is pretty much flat where the part will sit.

Updates will follow...

print_settings.Notes:: This model is designed to be assembled using srews.

description.text:
Here comes my lithophane miniature lamp!

This one is designed to attach a switch and a light source. In case you want it without the switch let me know in the comments.

Instructions:

  • Use the attached JPEG as an original for the correct dimensions of the lithophane.
  • Change the image to whatever you like (keep the format!)
  • Go to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/
  • Upload your image
  • Select "Outer Curve"
  • Go to settings > Model settings > Maximum size (MM) > Set it to 300 mm
  • Go to settings > Model settings > Curve > Set it to 360
  • In case you did not upload a negative image: Go to settings > Image settings > positive image
  • Click "Model" on top of the page
  • Hit "Refresh" button
  • Hit "Download" button to download and print your personal lithophane

Printing:

  • I recommend printing the parts orientated as they are downloaded
  • don't forget the supports when printing your top_plate

Selecting the light source:

  • Take the "adapter_piece" File (Sldprt or STL) and modifiy it so you can attach your own light source.
  • The adapter piece is designed to fit on the 3 holes on top of the litho_mount-plate
  • you can use the abatements to drill your own holes in the adapter piece

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1 - 0,2

Infill:

20 - 30%

Notes:

This model is designed to be assembled using srews.

Set-Up

You'll need:

  • 12V power supply
  • 12V light source, for example IKEA's LEDARE (you'll find some 12V light bulbs at IKEA).
  • standard switch to connect/disconnect your wiring.
  • fuse, only for safety reasons

Wire it up like this:

Power Supply 12V+ >>> Fuse || Fuse >>> Switch || Switch >>> Light bulb anode (+) || Light bulb cathode (-) >>> Power supply GND

The light bulb only as (+) and (-) connections in case of an LED. Normal light bulbs can also be connected the other way round, there is no specific connection. Just hook it up, so the current runs through it...

Nice design by the way.
Thanks

author: PurpleNurple

description.text:
This is a key I made for my sisters dolls house as she wanted to use it as a key for a fake lock.

I hope it helps you if you have a sister or daughter.

As always happy printing

This Sparse Cellular procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. I have also included PNG codec AVI versions, one of which "fades" at the edges (for making surfaces that don't end abruptly). These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats:
RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed
BMP sequence 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 17MB uncompressed
PNG codec AVI 256x256x256
PNG codec AVI 256x256x256 (faded 16vx at edges)
PLY isosurface mesh 1.5M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 730K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

remixed_from.author: Puddlefist
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 - Y-Axis Cable Chain - Right Side

title: Alunar 508 Prusa i3 Y-Axis Cable Chain

description.text: Here is my take on a Y-Axis cable chain. The Alunar printer appears to have a beefier chassis than most, so there is not enough room to squeeze in along side of the bed like the other solutions use.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.15 with a 0.3mm nozzle

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The chain links print OK without supports, you need a lot of them and you don't want to have to clean each one off. Lay them flat to print.

Use supports on the ends if necessary, but don't print them with the chain link pointed up, the "grain" of the print will make them too fragile.

Assembly

To make the chain, place the first piece on a flat surface and grab the second with the narrow end pointed out. Press it down firmly on the first one and the chamfer on the bottom will help it snap in place. I needed 16 links. The thinner chain worked for me, but there is a thicker link if required that also works with the ends.

Look at the second picture for the placement of the two mounting holes required for M4 nuts/bolts (My kit had spares).

Run the wires through both ends and the chain, mount the ends and snap on the chain.

Update:

After about 2 rolls of filament, the end on the chassis cracked. I replaced it with a beefier one.

comments.text: I really like your design!  I was wondering if this will work with the stock wingnuts, or do you think I'll need to print up the finger nobs for the leveling screws as well?

comments.text: I ran mine for a while with the wing nut, the bigger issue is the end of the screw protruding below the wingnut and catching on the chain. If your wires are long enough, I would re-locate it near the middle of the of the bed between the belt and the y-stop switch.

I just took some 10mm M3 nuts and bolts to assemble it. Not happy with the location of the nuts, especially the grounding bar is aweful - but it works.

I used 8mm carbon fiber rods cut to 50mm - simply because I had some spare ones left and it fits perfectly into the bobbins. They are not glued or fixed otherwise, they simply fit extremly tight (inserted them using a bench vise).

I will also apply some rubber pads as feets since it slides on the desk.

title: P3Steel z axis rod top MRZ105Z

description.text:
This is an alternative for centering the top of the Z axis threaded rod tor the P3Steel frame.

My frame is from Orballo, and it has a hole on the top for passing the threaded rod through, it is 12mm in diameter.

My threaded rod is 5mm.

I had a few MRZ105ZZ bearing in my stock. These have a 10mm external diameter, 5 mm internal diameter and 4mm thickness.

This part was designed to have one MRZ105ZZ inserted in it and then the whole assembly would be inserted in the top hole in the frame, thus keeping the Z axis centered.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with 0.5mm nozzle and 0.3mm layers, but smaller would probably look better.

description.text: A case for the Rock64 and a 2.5" drive. The drive sits in the bottom section, the Rock64 goes on the mounting plate and the lid has mounts for a pair of buck converters and a fan. Normal use is probably to skip the buck converters and use the standard power supply, but I have a tendency to over-engineer things.

Printer:

home built

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed with 0.5mm nozzle and 0.3mm layers, but smaller would probably look better.

Designed in OnShape

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/cf596ae8c53abbed82e9cafa/w/6a996b83c473efdc50f01eb3/e/1168e30024a1b05477af1a37

meter_mount.stl takes a small Volt meter such as https://www.ebay.ca/itm/Mini-DC-2-5-30V-0-36-Red-LED-Panel-Voltage-Meter-3-Digital-Display-Voltmeter/272551688932?hash=item3f7558bae4:g:CyEAAOSwr~lYnDag and simply glues into place

The two dc-dc converters provide 12V which supplies the fan and the second converter, and 5.2V for the SBC. Since the current draw on the 12V supply is lower than for the 5V a smaller converter can be used. I used a LM2596 for the 12V and XL4015 for the 5V.
e.g. https://www.ebay.ca/itm/DC-DC-Buck-Converter-Step-Down-Module-LM2596-Power-Supply-Output-1-25V-35V-/172130630915?hash=item2813c8fd03
and
https://www.ebay.ca/itm/1PCS-NEW-5A-XL4015-DC-DC-adjustable-step-down-module-4-38V-96-/182037148682?hash=item2a6242740a

The dual converter setup gives good regulation of the 5V line for inputs between about 6V and 16V (the highest I could easily test, it should be good for higher inputs up to about 30V). Inputs below 13V will reduce the fan speed.

I used a 50mm 12V fan (12mm thick). You could also use a 5V fan and potentially do away with the extra voltage converter, but you might get less accurate voltage regulation that way. It would also be possible to leave out the converters altogether and just use the standard PSU.

The large hole in the base allows heat from a HDD to escape. The HDD goes in face down so nothing too delicate is exposed. Strips of foam sheet can be used between the drive and the case to absorb vibration and noise. A set of rubber feet stuck to the bottom help with both cooling and noise reduction.

The fan control circuit is very generic using a ztx450 transistor driven from GPIO3_A5 (pin 16 on the Pi-2 bus).

author: Dinimedia

title: Snowflake Ornament Remixed from CAD to BlocksCAD

description.text:
I tried this challenge to see if it would work for my students, and the program was awesome. Bridges the gap between Scratch and CAD.

I took a design my five year old daughter and I worked from a sketch she drew and measured. Two weeks ago we drew it in CAD and this week I showed her how I remixed it by writing the design out with code. The designs are way different, but came from the same sketch. It would be very neat to have students draw out designs both ways to increase their understanding of design, patterns and of course code. I will definitely be writing this in as my hour of code lesson for the future if we get a grant for a 3D printer in our classroom.

I did have to export an OpenScad file and Render it with that program to get it to slice better. I included that file with the modifications for higher resolution cylinders and spheres. Very neat to learn all of these new design tricks to bring to my students!

title: External GPU Stand (Display / Mining)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My take on an external GPU stand for display or mining purposes. Inspired by b1sh0p's GPU Mining Rig design, but built entirely from scratch in Fusion 360 for any PCIe GPU and PCIe 1X to 16X risers that come with a padded bottom PCB.

The GPU can be fixed to the stand with a 4mm tapping screw at the top while the riser PCB is supported at the bottom by the stand's bottom support beams. I have included a printable pin that should hold the GPU in place, in case you don't want to or can't use a screw (untested).

The included pictures show a pre release version that didn't have supports for the riser PCB and was a tiny bit higher but worked flawlessly nonetheless. However I wasn't quite satisfied with the fact that the GPU/riser was howering 4mm above the bottom printed parts and opted for a redesign that allows for additional support in that area too.

I didn't have time to take pictures of the design I'm publishing now but I'll try to upload them as soon as possible.

Please let me know about your experiences in the comments and share your makes!

Thank you!

Taront3rD

200 micron

15%
